summary: The appellants, representing the people of Ogwu-Aniocha, claimed title to land known as ENUIGBO, including areas EYINGA and OGBUM, based on historical use, rental receipts, and a 1928 pledge to Chief Onyeama. The respondents, representing Amamputu-Uli, asserted ancestral ownership and argued that a 1939 inquiry under the Inter-Tribal Boundaries Settlement Ordinance had conclusively settled the boundary. That inquiry, conducted by Assistant District Officer Mr. Beaumont, arose after both parties withdrew Native Court actions. The trial judge found Chief Onyeama was representing the Ogwu-Aniocha people, whose chief, Okereke, testified and delineated the claimed boundaries. The appellants contended the settlement was between an individual (the pledgee) and a tribe, not inter-tribal. The Court of Appeal rejected this, holding that by supporting Onyeama’s claim and participating in the inquiry, the Ogwu-Aniocha people were bound by the outcome, either as parties or by estoppel through acquiescence. The appeal was dismissed.
citations: Roden v. London Small Arms Co., 46 L.J., Q.E.D., 213
Re Lart, Wilkinson v. Blades, 1896, 2 Ch. 788
rationaleHighlights: Settlement under Inter-Tribal Boundaries Settlement Ordinance binding on tribe even if represented by pledgee
Tribe's participation through representative constitutes party status
Acquiescence in proceedings estops later challenge
Title of pledgee identical to plaintiffs' title
Tribe benefited if claim succeeded, thus bound if it failed
Native Court actions withdrawn to allow administrative inquiry
Boundary decision confirmed by Senior Resident
